chapter: Audiometric tests and Special tests of hearing

questions.question:
Question 1: The audiogram of a patient with difficulty in hearing is given below. What is your 
interpretation?
questions.explanation:
The patient has left-sided conductive hearing loss. Interpretation of the above audiogram: • Blue color indicates left ear. • ] indicates BC and threshold is <25dB. BC is normal which means the sensorineural pathway is 
normal. • × indicates AC and threshold is >15 dB and hence AC is abnormal. • So, it indicates conductive deafness. • The air-bone gap is a feature of conductive hearing loss. • Hence, the chart is suggestive of left-sided conductive deafness. 277 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Audiometric tests and Special tests of hearing

questions.question:
Question 2: A middle-aged woman presents to the ENT OPD with complaints of difficulty in hearing. A 
pure tone audiometry test is performed and the result is given below. What is the 
interpretation? 268 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation: The given pure tone audiometry is suggestive of right-sided sensorineural deafness. Interpretation of the result: • Red indicates the right ear. • O indicates air conduction(AC). The threshold here is >15 dB indicating abnormal AC. • < indicates bone conduction(BC). The threshold is >25 dB indicating abnormal BC. • Both AC and BC are abnormal which indicates a sensorineural hearing loss. • There is no air-bone gap. • Hence, it is right side sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.question:
Question 3: The audiogram of a patient who presented with a gradually progressive hearing loss is given 
below. Which among the following would be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given audiogram is seen in Ménière's disease in its early stages. It shows an 
upsloping/ascending curve suggesting that the lower frequencies are affected first. Presbycusis, ototoxicity, and sound-induced hearing loss have downsloping audiograms since the 
higher frequencies are affected first in these conditions.
questions.chapter_heading: Audiometric tests and Special tests of hearing

questions.question:
Question 4: A 25-year-old woman presented with hearing loss that developed shortly after her first 
pregnancy. Her audiometry report is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario describes a patient with post-pregnancy hearing loss. The audiogram shows 
conductive deafness along with Carhart's notch (dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz). These 
findings are highly suggestive of otosclerosis. Ototoxicity, Meniere’s disease, and noise-induced hearing loss cause sensory neural hearing loss 
(SNHL) and not conductive hearing loss. Otosclerosis is caused by bony overgrowth involving the enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule. 
It presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It has an autosomal 
dominant inheritance and can worsen with stress and hormonal changes like during pregnancy 
and menopause. Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type of otosclerosis. Here the lesion starts just in front 
of the oval window in an area called fistula ante fenestrae. The presence of a reddish hue on the promontory through the tympanic membrane, known as the 
Schwartze sign, suggests an active focus. PTA shows loss of air conduction with air-bone gap, 
more for lower frequencies and Carhart's notch may be seen. Tympanometry shows an As type of 
tympanogram in which there is reduced compliance at or near the ambient air pressure. Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage. Definitive treatment is 
stapedectomy/stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis. Carhart notch usually disappears 278 
Sold by @itachibot after a successful stapedectomy. Other options: Option A: Ototoxicity causes SNHL and shows a high-frequency hearing loss in the SNHL curve. Option B: In Meniere's disease, pure tone audiometry shows an SNHL pattern with a rising curve 
in the early stages (as lower frequencies are involved first) and as the disease progresses higher 
frequencies are involved, the curve becomes flat or a falling type. Option D: Noise-induced hearing loss is SNHL and PTA shows a characteristic acoustic dip at 
4000 Hz both for air and bone conduction.

questions.question:
Question 5: A prisoner who was brought to the hospital with deafness after a brawl with another inmate is 
suspected of malingering. Which of the following tests can be used to assess the authenticity 
of his complaints?
questions.explanation:
Impedance audiometry can be used to test malingering. It is an objective test and consists of 
tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurements. A person who feigns total deafness and does not give any response on pure tone audiometry but 
shows a positive acoustic reflex is a malingerer.
questions.chapter_heading: Audiometric tests and Special tests of hearing

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient with hearing loss is being evaluated with the following instrument. What is the 
frequency of the probe used?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows impedance audiometry and the frequency of the probe used here is 220 
Hz. Impedance audiometry consists of tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurements. Tympanometry equipment consists of a probe that snugly fits into the external auditory canal and 
has three channels. • To deliver a tone of 220Hz • To absorb reflected sound • To change the pressure in EAC

Question 7: The tympanogram of a young patient who presented with a progressive hearing loss is given 
below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? 271 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The tympanogram shows As type of curve suggestive of otosclerosis. It indicates that pressure is 
normal but compliance is reduced.

questions.question:
Question 8: Using impedance audiometry, stapedial reflexes are being assessed in a child with cranial 
nerve palsy. Which of the following cranial nerves is being tested here?
questions.explanation:
The 7th and 8th cranial nerves are being tested in a child by assessing the stapedial reflexes. The afferent of stapedial reflex is the 8th cranial nerve and efferent is the 7th cranial nerve. 279 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: A woman is brought by her son to the ENT OPD due to hearing problems. He says that she 
always requests him to speak loud and whenever he speaks slightly louder, she tells him to 
stop shouting. Which of the following is the likely cause for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
The given symptom is indicative of a recruitment phenomenon and is seen in cochlear hearing 
loss (e.g. Ménière’s disease and presbycusis). It refers to abnormal growth of loudness. It is tested by ABLB (Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance) test. Lesser intensity sounds are heard 
louder in the normal ear. However, a greater intensity sound is heard equally, or even better in 
the abnormal ear. This is referred to as abnormal growth of loudness. However, in the conductive hearing loss, a constant difference of intensity is maintained 
throughout.
questions.chapter_heading: Audiometric tests and Special tests of hearing

questions.question:
Question 11: Patient with hearing loss undergoes speech audiometry whose report is given below. What is 
it suggestive of? 273 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given speech audiometry shows roll-over phenomenon suggestive of retrocochlear hearing 
loss. With an increase in speech intensity above a particular level, the speech discrimination score falls 
rather than maintaining a plateau as seen in the cochlear type of sensorineural hearing loss.
questions.chapter_heading: Audiometric tests and Special tests of hearing

questions.question:
Question 12: A middle-aged woman presents to you with a progressive hearing loss accompanied by 
tinnitus. An MRI of the patient with gadolinium contrast is given below. Which of the 
following results is consistent with the diagnosis?

options.a: <25 dB decay in threshold tone decay test

questions.explanation:
280 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario and the MRI are suggestive of vestibular schwannoma which is a 
retrocochlear disease. The presence of otoacoustic emissions is a feature consistent with the 
diagnosis. Vestibular schwannoma typically presents at 40-60 years of age. Progressive unilateral 
sensorineural hearing loss, often accompanied by tinnitus, is the presenting symptom in the 
majority of cases. The MRI shows left cerebellopontine angle mass causing widening of the porous acousticus. The 
mass is seen extending into intracanalicular portion of the internal acoustic meatus which is 
suggestive of vestibular schwannoma.
questions.chapter_heading: Audiometric tests and Special tests of hearing

questions.question: Question 13: What does summating potential in electrocochleography indicate?

options.c: Electrical activity of distal part of auditory nerve

questions.explanation:
Summating potential in electrocochleography indicates the sum of electrical activity in hair cells 
within the organ of Corti. Electrocochleography (ECoG) is an objective test which records the electrical activity of the 
cochlea and 8th nerve in response to auditory stimuli. The recording electrode is passed through 
the tympanic membrane to rest over the promontory. The three parameters measured in ECoG are: • Cochlear microphonics – measures the electrical activity that follows the stimulus and reflects 
the instantaneous displacement of the basilar membrane. • Summating potential (SP) – measures the electrical activity of the hair cells within the organ of 
Corti. • Action potential (AP) – electrical activity in the distal part of the auditory nerve. Normal SP: AP ratio is <30% but it is increased in Meniere’s disease.
questions.chapter_heading: Audiometric tests and Special tests of hearing

questions.question:
Question 14: A preterm neonate with an Apgar score of 4 at 5 minutes of birth undergoes otoacoustic 
emission study. Which of the following is false about this test?

options.a: Otoacoustic emissions are generated by inner hair cells
options.b: It is used as a screening test for hearing loss in infants
options.c: Spontaneous type is present in 50% of normal individuals
options.d: Evoked type is present in all individuals with normal hearing

questions.explanation:
The otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) are generated by the outer hair cells of the cochlea. Presence of 
otoacoustic emissions is used to test hearing in a high-risk neonate as given in the clinical 
scenario.

questions.question:
Question 15: Wave V in brainstem evoked response audiometry is produced by which of the following 
structures?
questions.explanation:
Wave V in BERA is produced by lateral lemniscus. The generators of ABEPs (Auditory nerve and brainstem evoked potentials) have been the subject 
of much research and controversy and are still not entirely agreed upon. The literature available to us states the following: 281 
Sold by @itachibot • Scott Brown's Otorhinolaryngology- wave IV–V complex probably arises from neural activity 
within the superior olivary complex and nuclei of the lateral lemniscus, possibly some 
contribution from the inferior colliculus. So lateral lemniscus is the better option. • Current Diagnosis and Treatment in Otorhinolaryngology- auditory brainstem response waves 2, 
3, 4, and 5 represent the sequential activation of neurons as the signal is passed up the brainstem 
from the proximal part of the cochlear nerve, cochlear nucleus, superior olivary complex, and 
lateral lemniscus. • NIH Journals- generation of wave V reflects the activity of multiple anatomic auditory 
structures. A sharp positive peak of wave V arises mainly from the lateral lemniscus, following a 
slow negative wave represents dendritic potential in the inferior colliculus.
questions.chapter_heading: Audiometric tests and Special tests of hearing

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient undergoes hearing assessment using cortical evoked response audiometry. Which of 
the following is false regarding this test? 275 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Recording is made from cortical potentials

questions.explanation:
In CERA or cortical evoked response audiometry, a tone stimulus is used instead of a click 
stimulus. It is an objective hearing test, that records the signals from the auditory cortex (part of the brain 
that recognizes sound) that have been generated in response to sounds introduced to the ears. The test gives information about the level of sound needed to produce a signal and confirms the 
status of the auditory cortex. This is valuable information that we can not obtain from a normal

questions.question:
Question 17: As a medical officer in an occupational health program, you encounter an employee with 
hearing loss. You are suspicious that he is faking it to claim compensation. Which of the 
following tests is least useful in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario is suggestive of malingering and Rinne's test is least useful here. Tests for malingering or nonorganic hearing loss: 282 
Sold by @itachibot • Stenger test • Lombard test • Stapedial reflex • Inconsistent results on repeat pure tone and speech audiometry tests • BERA

questions.question:
Question 18: While performing a caloric test, what type of nystagmus would you expect on cold water 
irrigation?

options.a: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
options.b: Vertical nystagmus towards the same side
options.c: Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
options.d: Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side

questions.explanation:
In caloric testing, cold water irrigation produces horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite 
side of irrigation. The direction of nystagmus can be remembered by the mnemonic, COWS 
(cold–opposite, warm–same). The mechanism for the nystagmus is the creation of a temperature gradient by the cold water, 
which pulls the cupula away from the utricle, causing nystagmus towards the oppsite side. As the 
horizontal semicircular canal is closer to the outer ear canal, most of the response comes from it 
and the nystagmus is horizontal. The Fitzgerald–Hallpike test (bithermal caloric test) is done to assess this phenomenon. The 
patient lies in a supine position with head tilted forward at a 30° angle, ensuring the horizontal 
canal becomes vertical. Alternatingly, water at temperatures of 30°C and 44°C (7° below and 
above normal body temperature, respectively) is irrigated into the ears for a duration of 40 
seconds each. The examiner closely observes the patient's eyes for the emergence of nystagmus 
until its endpoint is reached. The time taken from the start of irrigation to the endpoint of 
nystagmus is recorded and plotted on a calorigram. If no nystagmus is evoked from either ear, the test is repeated with water at a temperature of 20°C 
for a duration of 4 minutes before labeling the labyrinth dead. A 5-minute interval should be 
allowed between testing each ear to ensure accurate results.
questions.chapter_heading: Audiometric tests and Special tests of hearing

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing?
questions.explanation:
BERA, OAE, and tympanometry are the objective tests for hearing. PTA (pure tone audiometry) is 
a subjective test for hearing as it relies on patient responses to pure tone stimuli. Other examples 
of subjective tests include tuning fork tests and speech audiometry. Tympanometry is an objective test of the middle ear and eustachian tube functions (conductive 
compartment of hearing). Here, the compliance of the TM, i.e., how much it moves to the pressure 
differentials applied from the external ear is measured. The image below shows the types of tympanogram: 283 
Sold by @itachibot 284 
Sold by @itachibot Anatomy of Nose
